tn.text: This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here the author starts to tell a new part of the story.

tn.ref: Put your hand under my thigh
tn.text: Abraham was about to ask the servant to swear to do something. Putting his hand under Abraham's thigh would show that he would certainly do what he would swear to do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
This can be expressed as a command. AT: "swear" (See: [[;en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])
The term "swear by" means to use the name of something or someone as the basis or power on which the oath is made. "promise me with Yahweh as your witness"

tn.ref: the God of heaven and the God of the earth
tn.text: "the God of heaven and earth." The words "heaven" and "earth" are used together to mean every thing that God created. AT: "the God of everything in heaven and earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
This refers to the place where God lives.

tn.ref: from the daughters of the Canaanites
tn.text: "from the Canaanite women" or "from the Canaanites." This refers to Canaanite females.

tn.ref: among whom I make my home
tn.text: "among whom I live." Here, "I" stands for Abraham and all of his family and servants. AT: "among whom we live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This can be stated as a command. AT: "Swear that you will go" or "But go" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_imperative]])
"my family"
"What should I do if"

tn.ref: will not be willing to follow me
tn.text: "will not follow me" or "refuses to come back with me"

tn.ref: Must I take your son back to the land from which you came
tn.text: "Should I take you son to live in the land from which you came"

tn.ref: Make sure that you do not take my son back there
tn.text: The phrase "Make sure" emphasizes the command that follows."Be careful not to take my son back there" or "You definitely must not take my son there"

tn.ref: who took me from my father's house
tn.text: Here "house" stands for the people in his family. AT: "who took me from my father and the rest of my family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: promised me with a solemn oath
tn.text: "swore an oath to me"

tn.ref: saying, 'To your offspring I will give this land,'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. It can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "saying that he would give this land to my offspring" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
The words "he" and "his" refer to Yahweh.
Verse 8 is a continuation of the instructions Abraham gave his servant.

tn.ref: But if the woman is not willing to follow you
tn.text: "But if the woman refuses to come with you." Abraham was answering the servant's question from [[:en:bible:notes:gen:24:05|24:5]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: you will be free from this oath of mine
tn.text: "you will be released from the oath you made to me." Not having to fulfill an oath is spoken of as if the person is free from an object to which he was bound. AT: "you will not have to do what you swore to me that you would do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: put his hand under the thigh of Abraham his master
tn.text: This was to show that he would certainly do what he was swearing to do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"made an oath to him"
"concerning Abraham's request" or "that he would do what Abraham said"
The sentence starting with "He also took" gives additional information about what the servant took with him on the journey. He gathered them before he departed.

tn.ref: He also took with him all kinds of gifts from his master
tn.text: This means he also took many good things that his master wanted to give to the woman's family.
"set out and went" or "he left and went"
Possible meanings are 1) the city where Nahor lived" or 2) "the city called Nahor." If you can translate it without choosing a meaning, do so. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: He made the camels kneel down
tn.text: Camels are tall animals with long legs. He made them bend their legs and lower their bodies to the ground. "He made the camels lie down"
"water well" or "well" (UDB)
"get water" (UDB)
"Then the servant said"

tn.ref: grant me success today and show covenant faithfulness to my master Abraham
tn.text: You can state this with the connecting word "by." This makes clear how the servant wants God to show covenant faithfulness. AT: "Show covenant faithfulness to my master Abraham by granting me success today" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])

"give me success." The servant wanted to find a good wife for Abraham's son. The abstract noun "success" can be stated as a verb. AT: "help me to succeed" or "make me able to do what I have come here to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: show covenant faithfulness to my master Abraham
tn.text: This is faithfulness because of the covenant that God made with Abraham. The abstract noun "faithfulness" can be stated as "be faithful." AT: "be faithful to my master Abraham because of your covenant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here the word "Look" adds emphasis to what follows.
"the spring" or "the well"

tn.ref: the daughters of the men of the city
tn.text: "the young women of the city"
"Let it happen this way" or "Make this happen"

tn.ref: When I say to a young woman, 'Please lower your pitcher so that I may drink,'
tn.text: This is a quotation within a quotation. This can be expressed with an indirect quote. AT: "When I ask a young woman to let me have a drink of water from her jar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
The women carried the pitchers on their shoulder. She would have to lower it to give the man a drink.
a medium-size jar made of clay used for holding and pouring liquids

tn.ref: that you have shown covenant faithfulness to my master
tn.text: The abstract noun "faithfulness" can be stated as "been faithful." AT: "that you have been faithful to my master because of your covenant" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This phrase is used here to mark where the action starts. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.
The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.
This is a medium-size jar made of clay used for holding and pouring liquids. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:24:12|24:14]].

tn.ref: Rebekah was born to Bethuel son of Milcah, the wife of Nahor, Abraham's brother
tn.text: "Rebekah's father was Bethuel. Bethuel's parents were Milcah and Nahor. Nahor was Abraham's brother"
Bethuel was Rebekah's father. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:22:20|22:22]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a man. See how you translated his name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:11:22|11:22]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Milcah was Nahor's wife and Bethuel's mother. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:11:29|11:29]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: She went down to the spring ... and came up
tn.text: The spring was somewhere lower in elevation than where the servant was standing.
"to meet the young woman"
"a little water"
This is a medium-size jar made of clay used for holding and pouring liquids. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:24:12|24:14]].
"sir." Here the woman uses this term of respect to refer to the man, though she is not his slave.

tn.ref: she quickly let down her pitcher on her hand
tn.text: "she quickly lowered her pitcher." She was carrying the pitcher on her shoulder. She had to lower it to get water for the servant.
"I will get water"

tn.ref: So she hurried and emptied her pitcher
tn.text: "So she quickly emptied her pitcher"
"the animals' water trough" (UDB). A trough is a long open container for holding water for animals to drink.
"The servant" (UDB)
"watched Rebekah" or "watched the young woman"
Learning something is often spoken of as if it were seeing. AT: "to know" (UDB) or "to determine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

"had fulfilled the purpose of his journey" or "had made his journey successful." You can make explicit what specifically the servant was trying to determine. AT: "was showing him the woman who would become Isaac's wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
You can state clearly the understood information. AT: "or not prospered his journey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: a gold nose ring weighing half a shekel
tn.text: "a gold nose ring that weighed six grams" (UDB). The weight indicates the value of the ring. AT: "an expensive gold nose ring" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])

tn.ref: two gold bracelets for her arms weighing ten shekels
tn.text: "two gold bracelets for her arms that weighed 110 grams." The weight shows their size and value. AT: "two large gold bracelets for her arms" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bweight]])
"Who is your father"

tn.ref: is there room in your father's house
tn.text: "is there a place in your father's house"
Apparently other men went on this journey with Abraham's servant. Here "us" refers to the servant and those traveling with him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]]
"to stay tonight" or "to stay for the night"
"Rebekah said" or "the young woman said"
"to the servant"

tn.ref: I am the daughter of Bethuel son of Milcah, whom she bore to Nahor
tn.text: "Bethuel is my father, and his parents are Milcah and Nahor"

tn.ref: We have plenty of both straw and feed
tn.text: It is understood that the straw and feed are for the camels. You can make clear this understood information. AT: "We have plenty of straw and feed for the camels" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: for you to spend the night
tn.text: "for you to stay tonight" or "where you can stay for the night"
Here "you" refers to the servant and those traveling with him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"the servant" (UDB)
This is a sign of humility before God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: has not forsaken his covenant faithfulness and his trustworthiness toward my master
tn.text: "has not stopped showing his covenant faithfulness and trustworthiness to my master." The abstract nouns "faithfulness" and "trustworthiness" can be stated as "to be faithful and trustworthy." AT: "has continued to be faithful and trustworthy because of his covenant with my master" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This can be stated in positive form. AT: "continues to show" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
"family" or "clan"

tn.ref: ran and told her mother's household
tn.text: Here "household" stands for all the people living in her mother's house. AT: "ran to the house and told her mother and everyone there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"everything that had just happened"

This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here the author tells background information about Rebekah. The author introduces her brother, Laban, to the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])

tn.ref: When he had seen the nose ring ... and when he had heard the words of Rebekah his sister
tn.text: These things happened before he ran out to the man. This tells why Laban ran out to the man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_events]])

tn.ref: when he had heard the words of Rebekah his sister, "This is what the man said to me,"
tn.text: This can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "when he had heard his sister Rebekah tell what the man had said to her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
"indeed." The word "behold" here adds emphasis to what follows.
"Come in" or "Enter"
"you whom Yahweh has blessed"
Here the word "you" refers to Abraham's servant. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

Laban used this question to invite Abraham's servant into his house. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "You do not need to stay outside." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: So the man came to the house
tn.text: The word "came" can be translated as "went." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])

It is not clear who did this work. This may be stated in active form. AT: "Laban's servants unloaded the camels" (UDB) or "the camels were unloaded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The camels were given straw and feed, and water was provided
tn.text: This does not say who did the work. If you state this in active form use "Laban's servants" as the subject. AT: "Laban's servants gave straw and feed to the camels, and they provided water" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"for Abraham's servant and the men who were with him to wash their feet"
Here, the word "they" refers to Laban's family members or to the household servants.
"gave food to the servant"

tn.ref: said what I have to say
tn.text: "spoken my words" or "told you why I am here"
Here the word "he" refers to Abraham.
"become very wealthy"
The word "he" refers to Yahweh.
Abraham's servant continues speaking to Rebekah's family.

tn.ref: bore a son to my master
tn.text: "gave birth to a son"
"my master has given ... to his son"

tn.ref: My master made me swear, saying
tn.text: "My master made me swear that I would do what he told me to do. He said"

tn.ref: from the daughters of the Canaanites
tn.text: This refers to Canaanite females. AT: "from the Canaanite women" or "from the Canaanites"

tn.ref: in whose land I make my home
tn.text: "among whom I live." Here, "I" stands for Abraham and all of his family and servants. AT: "among whom we live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"to my own clan" (UDB)
Abraham's servant continues speaking to Rebekah's family.

tn.ref: Perhaps the woman will not follow me
tn.text: This is something that could possibly happen. AT: "What if the woman will not come back with me." or "What should I do if the woman will not come back with me?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
Serving Yahweh is spoken of as if Abraham were walking in Yahweh's presence. AT: "whom I serve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"he will make your journey successful"
"family"

tn.ref: But you will be free from my oath if you come to my relatives and they will not give her to you. Then you will be free from my oath
tn.text: This is a hypothetical situation that Abraham did not think was likely to happen. Possible meanings are 1) "There is only one way for you to be free from my oath: if you come to my relatives and they will not give her to you, then you will be free from my oath" or, 2) building on verse 40, "If you go to my father's family and ask for a girl, you will have done what I told you to do. If they will not give her to you, then you will be free from the oath you swore to me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: you will be free from my oath
tn.text: "you will be released from the oath you made to me." Not having to fulfill an oath is spoken of as if the person is free from an object to which he was bound. AT: "you will not have to do what you swore to me that you would do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: if you come to my relatives
tn.text: Languages use the words come and go differently. AT: "if you arrive at my relatives' home" or "if you go to my relatives" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
Abraham's servant continues speaking to Rebekah's family.
"the well"

tn.ref: here I am, standing by the spring of water
tn.text: The servant interrupted what he was asking God to do by drawing God's attention to where he was standing.

tn.ref: let the young woman who comes ... the woman to whom I say ... the woman who says to me
tn.text: The servant went back to stating his request, and he had three things to say about the woman that he hoped would come.
"to get water"
This is a medium-size jar made of clay used for holding and pouring liquids. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:24:12|24:14]].
The servant finished his request.
Abraham's servant continues speaking to Rebekah's family.

To pray silently in one's mind is spoken of as if he were speaking in his heart. The word "heart" refers to his thoughts and his mind. AT: "praying" (UDB) or "praying quietly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"indeed" or "suddenly." The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.
This is a medium-size jar made of clay used for holding and pouring liquids. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:24:12|24:14]].

tn.ref: she went down to the spring
tn.text: The phrase "went down" is used because the spring was somewhere lower than where the servant was standing.
"well"
"gave water to the camels"
Abraham's servant continues speaking to Rebekah's family.

tn.ref: The daughter of Bethuel, Nahor's son, whom Milcah bore to him
tn.text: "My father is Bethuel. His parents are Nahor and Milcah"
In this story, all of these items were made of gold. See how you translated these in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:24:21|24:22]].
This is a sign of humility before God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: led me by the right way
tn.text: "brought me here"
The connecting word "because" can be used to show this is why the servant worshiped God. AT: "because Yahweh led me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_connectingwords]])
This refers to Bethuel, the son of Abraham's brother Nahor.
Abraham's servant continues speaking to Rebekah's family.
"Now" (UDB). Here "Now" does not mean "at this moment," but is used to draw attention to the important point that follows.

tn.ref: if you are prepared to treat my master with family faithfulness and trustworthiness, tell me
tn.text: How they could show their faithfulness and trustworthiness can be stated explicitly. AT: "tell me if you will be faithful and trustworthy to my master by giving Rebekah to be his son's wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The word "you" refers to Laban and Bethuel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
These abstract nouns can be stated as "faithful and trustworthy." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
This is faithfulness to family members.
The understood information can be stated clearly. AT: "But if you are not prepared to treat my master with family faithfulness and trustworthiness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: so that I may turn to the right hand, or to the left
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) deciding what to do is spoken of as if the person will physically turn one direction or another. AT: "so that I will know what do" or 2) the servant wants to know if he needs to travel somewhere else. AT: "so that I may continue on my journey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This was the father of Laban and Rebekah.

tn.ref: The thing has come from Yahweh
tn.text: "Yahweh has caused all of this to happen"

tn.ref: we cannot speak to you either bad or good
tn.text: They are saying they do not have the authority to decide whether what God has done is good or bad. AT: "we dare not judge what Yahweh is doing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The word "Look" here adds emphasis to what follows.
"Here is Rebekah"
"Laban and Bethuel's words." Here "words" stands for what they said. AT: "what Laban and Bethuel said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Bowing down before God is an expression of worship to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: articles of silver and articles of gold
tn.text: "silver and gold items" or "things made of silver and gold"
"expensive gifts" or "valuable gifts"

tn.ref: he and the men who were with him
tn.text: "Abraham's servant and his men"
"slept there that night"
"got up the next morning"
"Let me leave and return"

tn.ref: a few more days, at least ten
tn.text: "at least ten more days"
"10" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"Then"
"Abraham's servant said"
"to Rebekah's brother and mother"
"Do not delay me" (UDB) or "Do not make me wait"
Here "way" stands for a journey. AT: "Yahweh has caused me to succeed in the purpose my journey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Allow me to leave"

tn.ref: So they sent their sister Rebekah
tn.text: "So the family sent Rebekah"
Rebekah was Laban's sister. AT: "their relative" or "Laban's sister"
This refers to the female servant who had fed Rebekah when she was a baby, cared for her when she was a child, and still served her.
Rebekah was not the sister to everyone in her family. But they called her this to show that they loved her. AT: "Our dear Rebekah"

tn.ref: may you be the mother of thousands of ten thousands
tn.text: Here "mother" stands for ancestor. AT: "may you be the ancestor of millions of people" or "may you have very many descendants"
This means a very large number or an uncountable number. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: may your descendants possess the gate of those who hate them
tn.text: Armies would break through the gate of their enemies' cities and conquer the people. AT: "may your descendants completely defeat those who hate them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Then Rebekah arose, and she and her servant girls mounted the camels
tn.text: "Then Rebekah and her servant girls went and got on the camels"

tn.ref: Thus the servant took Rebekah, and went his way
tn.text: "In this way Abraham's servant took Rebekah with him and returned to where he had come from"
This word marks a change in the story. It was telling about the servant finding a wife, and now it will tell about Isaac.
This is the name of a water well in the Negev. See how you translated it in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:16:13|16:14]].

tn.ref: Isaac went out to meditate in the field in the evening
tn.text: "One evening Isaac went out to the field to think." This must have been a long time after the servant and Rebekah left her home since they had to travel a long distance.

tn.ref: When he looked up and saw, behold, there were camels coming!
tn.text: The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows. "When he looked up he was surprised to see camels coming"
"Rebekah looked up"

tn.ref: she jumped down from the camel
tn.text: "she quickly got off the camel"

tn.ref: So she took her veil, and covered herself
tn.text: "So she covered her face with her veil." This is a sign of respect and modesty towards the man she will marry. The full meaning of this can be made explicit. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
a piece of cloth used to cover a person's head, shoulders and face

tn.ref: and took Rebekah, and she became his wife
tn.text: Both of these phrases mean that Isaac married Rebekah. AT: "and married Rebekah" or "and took her as his wife" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "So Rebekah comforted Isaac" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
